anchors: How can the efficiency of an open type cycle system be improved in an upper stage engine?
positives: The system cycle efficiency of a cycle of the open type can be increased by attaching a nozzle of high expansion ratio to the turbine exhaust duct, in case of an engine for an upper stage, or by post-combusting the gas exhausted by the turbine with additional propellant into an after-burner, as is the case with the engine of a supersonic jet aircraft. The system cycle efficiency of a cycle of the open type ranges from 0.96 to 0.99 [22]..

anchors: What is the pressure condition required at the turbine exhaust in a closed-type cycle compared to the combustion chamber?
positives: In acycle of the closed type, the gas exhausted by the turbine is firstly ducted into the main combustion chamber in order to be burned again with one of the propellants, and then ejected through the nozzle attached to the main combustion chamber. A cycle of the closed type requires a pressure of the gas at the turbine exhaust higher than the pressure of the gas in the combustion chamber. Therefore, in a cycle of the closed type, the pressures of the propellants at the discharge of the pumps are higher and the turbine pressure ratio is much lower than is the case with a cycle of the open type.

anchors: What type of gas is typically utilized as the working fluid in a closed cycle to drive a turbine?
positives: In most cases, a gas composed of 100% of combustion products of one propellant and part of the other propellant is used in a cycle of the closed type as the working fluid which drives the turbine..

anchors: What key factors influence the performance of a rocket engine and can affect its ability to fulfill its mission?
positives: The performance of an individual rocket engine depends on its thrust, specific impulse, mass flow rate, and oxidiser-to-fuel mixture ratio. Each engine is designed to operate at a performance level defined by the values of the quantities indicated above. Another engine, even of the same type, may operate at performance parameters which are slightly different from the design values. When the deviations of the actual from the nominal performance values are greater than a few percent, then a rocket vehicle may be incapable of accomplishing its mission..

anchors: What factors can affect the efficiency of the combustion process in propellant injectors, according to Sutton and Biblarz?
positives: These deviations are due to several reasons. Sutton and Biblarz [30] have identified some of them, which are specified below. Firstly, the unavoidable tolerances on the construction materials may alter the impingement of the propellants in the injector, and this change may affect the efficiency of the combustion process. Secondly, a change in mixture ratio, even small, may cause an increase in unused propellant at the end of the burn.

anchors: What factors can lead to deviations in propellant performance parameters from their intended design values?
positives: The quantity of residual propellant ranges usually from 0.5 to 2% of the total quantity [31]. Thirdly, variations in either the composition or the storage temperature of the propellants may induce changes in their density and viscosity. Fourthly, regulator setting tolerances or changes in flight acceleration can also cause deviations of the performance parameters from the design values..

anchors: What is the primary purpose of adjusting parameters in an engine calibration process?
positives: The engine calibration system is a process which corrects an engine system, by adjusting the values of its parameters, in order to obtain the desired performance within the allowed limits of tolerance.The engine components which need calibration are e hydraulic and pneumatic components, such as pumps, pipes, valves, expansion

anchors: What are the essential components required for handling high-temperature and cryogenic propellant applications in rocket propulsion systems?
positives: e high-temperature components, such as thrust chamber, turbines, gas generators or pre-burners, etc.; and © components for cryogenic propellants, such as pumps, valves etc.

anchors: How are components evaluated for their pressure drops in a controlled test environment?
positives: Hydraulic and pneumatic components are tested by means of water flowing through them in flow benches. This makes it possible to determine their pressure drops at rated conditions. Components operating at high temperatures are tested through hot firing. Likewise, components operating at low temperature are tested by using cryogenic propellants or liquid nitrogen.

anchors: How are engine properties evaluated in relation to pressure drops across its components and the targeted mass flow rates?
positives: The engine properties are estimated by summing the corrected values of the pres- sure drops due to its individual components at the desired mass flow rates. In addition, the actual measured mixture ratio si, /imy must be equal to the desired mixture ratio

anchors: What are the two methods for managing engine performance parameters, and how do they differ in their approach to control?
positives: Two methods can be employed to control the performance parameter of an engine. The first of them uses an automatic system with feedback and a digital computer which controls the deviations of the parameters in real time. The other method uses an initial static calibration of the engine system. In particular, the pressures supplied to the propellants by means of the respective pumps (or by means of gases under pressure, in case of gas-pressurised propellants) must be balanced against the pressure drops and the pressure in the combustion chamber.

anchors: What is required for an engine to function properly regarding mass flow rates and the ratio of oxidiser to fuel?
positives: This balancing is necessary in order for an engine to operate at the desired values of the mass flow rates and of the oxidiser-to-fuel mixture ratio o/f. anchors: What factors must be changed during testing to derive calibration curves for a pump?
positives: The rotation speed of a pump is a variable quantity. The pump calibration curves can only be drawn after obtaining data resulting from tests. Such tests are executed by varying the impeller diameter (impeller trimming) and the hydraulic resistances at the discharge, in order to obtain the properties required by engine system.

anchors: What is necessary to ensure that the energy supplied at the turbine shaft matches the total power required for pumps and associated losses?
positives: The volume flow rate of the propellants to either a gas generator or a pre-burner also needs calibration. The power balance requires the power delivered at the turbine shaft to be equal to the sum of the power needed to drive the pumps and the power losses in the bearings, seals, etc.

anchors: What factors are combined with assumed quantities to predict pump head rise, pump flow rate, and turbine flow rate in a turbo-pump design?
positives: Ina system balance of a turbo-pump at the initial point of design, known quantities (such as engine type, pressure in the thrust chamber, expansion area ratio in the nozzle, oxidiser-to-fuel mixture ratio, and thrust) are combined with assumed quantities (such as pump efficiencies, turbine efficiencies, turbine pressure ratio, turbine inlet temperature, and various indicators of engine performance), in order to predict the requirements relating to the pump head rise, the pump flow rate, and the turbine flow rate.

anchors: How is the power supplied to the turbine shaft related to the various sources of power consumption?
positives: In making this balance, the power delivered to the turbine shaft is equated to all the sources of power absorption, as has been shown above..

anchors: Why is it important to maintain system balance in a turbo-pump during the final design stage of a rocket engine?
positives: A system balance of a turbo-pump is also necessary at the final point of design. This is because refinements and changes, which may be made in the detailed design of a rocket engine, can affect the turbo-pump operation. For example, during the development of the engine of the MA-5 sustainer, the efficiencies of the pumps and of the turbine were found, when tested, below the initial values assumed for them in the design balance of the engine system.

anchors: What adjustments were necessary to enhance the turbine drive pressure from the gas generator to achieve the specified thrust output?
positives: This fact required changes to increase the  value of the turbine drive pressure available from the gas generator, in order for the engine to meet its rated thrust values..

anchors: What potential issues can arise from a turbo-pump operating outside its intended conditions?
positives: An off-design operating condition of a turbo-pump may be more demanding for a particular component than the nominal design condition. Consequently, the whole operating range of a rocket engine is to be considered carefully. Otherwise, a pump which operates satisfactorily in design conditions may perform unsatisfactorily or even fail in off-design conditions.

anchors: What factors must be considered to accurately define the full operational range of a turbo-pump beyond its planned specifications?
positives: In order to define the actual operating range of a turbo-pump, it is necessary to determine the planned operating range. Then, a system balance including the predicted operating characteristics of the turbo-pump is used to determine the whole range of operation over the planned engine throttling and the variation of the oxidiser- to-fuel mixture ratio. For this purpose, it is necessary to take account not only of the ordinary variations in the operating conditions, but also of the variations due to manufacturing tolerances.

anchors: What type of data is essential for estimating tolerances on hydraulic resistance and flow characteristics in liquid-propellant engine components?
positives: This requires the availability of data on known tolerances of components from existing liquid-propellant engines. These data are used to esti- mate tolerances on hydraulic resistance of lines, valves, and passage channels of the coolant in the nozzle, tolerances on the head rise/flow rate and efficiency/flow rate curves of the pump, etc..

anchors: What statistical method is used to assess the overall impact of component tolerances in the system?
positives: The tolerances on all the components are assumed to have a Gaussian distribution. The effects of these tolerances are treated statistically, by taking the square root of the sum of the squares of the effects of all the components. The effect of each component is determined either by performing an engine balance assuming that the given component is at one of the extreme points of its range of tolerance, or by linearising the equations which govern the engine system in order to determine the influence coefficients for each of the components considered..

anchors: What methods are employed to regulate the gas flow rate to the turbine and oxidiser flow rate to the gas generator in rocket engines?
positives: The control points used for regulating the thrust and the oxidiser-to-fuel mixture ratio can affect the discharge pressure of the turbo-pump and therefore its system design. Either calibration orifices or a pressure regulator have been used to control either the gas flow rate from the gas generator to the turbine or the oxidiser flow rate to the gas generator. For the J-2, F-1, and H-1 rocket engines, calibration orifices have been used in the turbine-gas generator lines to set the power level.

anchors: What method is employed by the RL10 engine to manage turbine power using heated hydrogen?
positives: For the RL10 engine, heated fuel (hydrogen) has been used to control the turbine power. For this purpose, the fuel was heated by passing through the cooling jacket of the thrust chamber before being ducted to the turbine through a control system which sensed the thrust chamber pressure and adjusted a turbine bypass valve. By contrast, the MA-5 and MB-S rocket engines used a pressure regulator to control the flow of the oxidiser to the gas generator..

anchors: How do the MA-5 sustainer and J-2 engine differ in regulating the proportion of oxidiser to fuel?
positives: The control of the oxidiser-to-fuel mixture ratio has been obtained by using either the main propellant valves or a valve controlling the bypass of a propellant around its pump. The engine of the MA-5 sustainer used the control of the main propellant valves, whereas the J-2 engine used a control valve around the oxidiser pump to regulate the oxidiser-to-fuel mixture ratio.

anchors: What type of combustion cycle is affected by significant changes in pump discharge pressure due to mixture ratio variations in its control system?
positives: Engines which use orifices in the gas generator feed lines for thrust calibration or a turbine bypass for mixture ratio regulation are subject to large changes in thrust level, and therefore in pump discharge pressure, when their mixture ratio is varied.  This type of control system is unsuitable for high-pressure staged-combustion cycles, because of the high variations in the pump discharge pressure as a result of the series arrangement of the thrust chamber, the turbine, and the turbine hot-gas generator [12]..

anchors: What aspects of centrifugal-flow pump design are addressed with quantitative measurements?
positives: Centrifugal-flow pumps have been illustrated and described qualitatively in the preceding sections. Here, their design is described quantitatively.

anchors: What is the difference in direction of fluid entry and exit in a centrifugal pump's impeller?
positives: The impeller of a centrifugal pump is a bladed rotor shaped so as to sweep the pumped fluid roughly z/2 rad (or 90°) outward from the pump shaft. The fluid enters the pump in the axial direction and is swept radially by the rotating blades of the impeller. The following figure, due to the courtesy of Wikimedia [32], illustrates a rubber impeller shaped as a paddle-wheel, which has been used for the water pump of an outboard engine..

positives: Let r; (m) and r2 (m), such that r; <r, be the radii defining the endpoints of an impeller blade at the points of respectively entrance and exit of the fluid. The tangential component of the velocity vector acting on a fluid particle increases, as the particle moves radially from the point of radius r, to the point of radius r2, due to the centrifugal force acting on the particle. Assuming a constant angular velocity @ (rad/s) of the shaft, and in the absence of energy losses, the ideal head rise AH;- (m) of the fluid between the entrance and the exit of the impeller is.

anchors: What type of tip design is featured in the inducer with a low head coefficient of 0.11 used in a rocket engine pump?
positives: This figure illustrates an inducer having a low head coefficient (WwW = 0.11), a cylindrical tip, and a tapered hub. This particular inducer has been used in the Mark-15 liquid-oxygen pump for the J-2 rocket engine. The complete Mark-15 liquid-oxygen pump is illustrated in Sect. 4.7.

anchors: What effect does an inducer have on the angle of flow entering and exiting the impeller in a pumping system?
positives: The presence of an inducer modifies the flow entering the impeller of a pump. In particular, the flow enters the impeller at an angle f; greater than the impeller inlet vane angle 6, and leaves the impeller at an angle 85 smaller than the impeller discharge vane angle B>.

positives: dimp = 1+ Ge where q (m/s) is the rated flow rate of the pump, and g, (m/s) is the impeller loss due to leakage (see Sect. 4.7). Typical design values of the leakage loss q, range from 0.01 Gimp to 0.05 gimp [22].

anchors: What parameters must a designer consider when selecting velocities and angles for the vanes of a centrifugal-flow pump impeller to optimize efficiency?
positives: In the design of a centrifugal-flow pump, the values of some quantities, such as head rise AH (m), volume flow rate g (m/s), rotating speed w (rad/s), specific speed N, and suction specific speed S, are chosen by the designer. This done, the impeller for this pump is designed by choosing the velocities and the angles of its vanes in such a way as to obtain the desired properties with the maximum efficiency.

anchors: What parameters are essential for the design of an impeller related to pump efficiency and performance?
positives: For this purpose, it is possible to use design or experimental data on pump head coefficient vw, impeller vane coefficient ¢,, and impeller loss due to leakage q, (m/s). Finally, the impeller is designed according to the chosen values of the quantities mentioned above. .

anchors: What factors influence the radial component of absolute flow velocity at an impeller's entrance?
positives: The values of some principal quantities are chosen as will be shown below.The radial component c,,; (m/s) of the absolute flow velocity at the impeller entrance depends on the inlet conditions, and in particular on the velocity of discharge at the outlet of the inducer, and on the diameter of the duct. Typical design values of Cm tange from 3.05 to 18.3 m/s [22].

anchors: What factors influence the radial component of the absolute flow velocity at the exit of the impeller?
positives: The radial component c,,2 (m/s) of the absolute flow velocity at the impeller exit depends on the outlet conditions, and in particular on the tip velocity uz (m/s) of the impeller blades and on the flow coefficient g = C,,2/u2 at the impeller exit. Typical design values of c,,2 range from 0.01 wz to 0.15 uz [22].

anchors: What factors influence the diameter of the impeller at the entrance of the vanes?
positives: The diameter d, (m) of the impeller at the point of entrance of the vanes depends on the design of the inducer, on the diameter of the impeller shaft, and on the diameter of the impeller hub.

anchors: What factors influence the maximum design value of impeller blade velocity at the exit in a single-stage impeller?
positives: The tip velocity uw (m/s) of the impeller blades at the impeller exit can be computed by means of the equation y = go AH /u5, for given values of the head rise AH (m) and of the head coefficient y. The maximum design value of u2 depends on the strength of the material used. The latter, in turn, determines the maximum head rise which can be obtained with a single-stage impeller. Typical design values of uz range from 61 to 457 m/s [22].

anchors: How is the impeller diameter calculated using the known values of rotating speed and tip velocity?
positives: When the rotating speed w (rad/s) and the tip velocity u (m/s) have known values, then the impeller diameter d2 (m) at the point of exit can be computed as follows dz = 2u2/w..

anchors: What is the typical range for the angle measured in radians for optimal vane design in relation to inlet flow conditions?
positives: The inlet vane angle 6; depends on the flow conditions at the vane inlet. The angle 6, should be made equal or close to the inlet flow angle 6. Remembering the preceding equationCul = Uy — ot tan B; it is possible to calculate approximately the angle f; as follows tan B, = a : Wy CytTypical design values of 6; range from 0.1396 to 0.5236 rad [22].

positives: The outlet vane angle £2 is equal to 2/2 rad in the particular case of an impeller having radial vanes, as has been shown above. In case of an impeller having backward- curved vanes, {> is to be determined by considering the curves expressing efficiency and head rise against volume flow rate. For a given value of the impeller peripheral velocity uz at outlet, the head rise and the volume flow rate increase with increasing values of 62.

anchors: How is the yield load calculated in relation to the design limit load?
positives: The shaft torque and the shaft bending moment correspond to either the yield load or the ultimate load. The yield load is determined by multiplying the design limit load by the factor 1.1, and the ultimate load is determined by multiplying the design limit load by the factor 1.5.

positives: These contraction factors take account of the reduction of the effective flow area due to the thickness of the vanes and to local circulatory flows..

anchors: What characteristics make impellers with a low number of blades preferable in manufacturing processes?
positives: From the point of view of manufacturing, impellers with a low number of blades are desirable. Impellers with blades curved backward (82 < m/2 rad) and low head coefficient w = go AH/u3 tend to have a wider and more stable operating range than impellers with radial blades (62 = 2/2 rad). However, the range of high efficiency for pumps with impellers of low head coefficient is smaller than the corresponding range for pumps with impellers of high head coefficient [3]..

anchors: What type of titanium alloy is commonly used for fabricating impellers with high tip speeds for special pumping applications?
positives: Impellers are fabricated by casting, machining, and diffusion bonding. Impellers having highest tip speeds (much above 300 m/s) are used for pumping liquid hydrogen. These impellers are of the open-face type, and are machined from high- strength forged materials, usually from the Ti-5AI-2.5Sn titanium alloy, extra-low- interstitial (ELI) grade. A figure illustrating one of such impellers for liquid-hydrogen pumps has been given in Sect.

anchors: What type of propellants are unshrouded machined impellers designed for in the Titan II rocket?
positives: 4.2. Shrouded impellers for dense fuels or oxidisers are cast, since the properties of cast materials are adequate for the required tip speeds of less than 300 m/s. Open-faced impellers for oxidiser pumps may be cast or machined. The following figure, due to the courtesy of NASA [5], illustrates unshrouded machined impellers for low-density propellants. These impellers have been used in the Titan II rocket..

anchors: What manufacturing processes are used for creating shrouded impellers in liquid-hydrogen pumps?
positives: Shrouded impellers for liquid-hydrogen pumps have been machined from forg- ings. They have also been fabricated by generating all the components separately from a titanium alloy, diffusion bonding them, and finishing internal passages by chemical milling [3].

anchors: What is the abbreviation for Unsymmetrical Di-Methyl Hydrazine in the context of liquid propellant applications?
positives: Impeller materials which have been used successfully with liquid propellants for rockets are shown in the following table, due to the courtesy of NASA [3]. FLOX is a mixture of liquid fluorine (LF) with liquid hydrogen (LH2). IRFNA stands for Inhibited Red Fuming Nitric Acid (HNO3). UDMH stands for Unsymmetrical Di- Methyl Hydrazine (H2NN(CH3)2). Inconel 718 is a trade name of Special Metals for a precipitation-hardening nickel-chromium-iron alloy.

anchors: What is the primary composition of the MONEL® alloy K-500?
positives: “K” Monel indicates the MONEL® alloy K-500, which is a trade name of Special Metals for a precipitation- hardenable alloy containing nickel, copper, and aluminium..

anchors: What is the function of the axial inlet portion of a pump rotor in preventing issues in subsequent stages?
positives: The following section of the present section is meant to give criteria for designing an inducer, which is the axial inlet portion of a pump rotor and has the function of raising the inlet head of the pumped fluid by an amount sufficient to preclude cavitation in the following stages. An inducer may be an integral part of a pump rotor,  but may also be matched separately to the pump shaft upstream of the pump impeller.

anchors: What is the primary goal of designing an inducer in relation to suction performance and structural stability?
positives: The principal objective in the design of an inducer is the attainment of high suction performance while maintaining structural integrity under all operating conditions [4]. An inducer is designed to operate at low inlet pressure under conditions of incipient cavitation, which fact permits a low pressure in the propellant tank. The inducer provides a sufficient head rise to avoid cavitation in the following stages of the pump [34].

anchors: What percentage range can the head increase attributed to the inducer achieve relative to the pump's total head rise?
positives: The head rise due to the inducer ranges from 5 to 20% of the head rise of the pump. The required head rise AH;,z (m) due to the inducer at the design point for a given pump is expressed by the following equation ABing = (NPSHR) imp — (NPSHR) ina where (NPSH g)imp (m) is the required net positive suction head due to the impeller, and (NPSH pr) ina (m) is the required net positive suction head due to the inducer.

anchors: What factors contribute to the increase in static pressure at the leading edge of an inducer's vanes?
positives: The principal increase in static pressure in an inducer occurs at the leading edge of its vanes, because the velocity of the flow decreases there with respect to the vanes, and also because the angle of attack between the inlet flow and the vanes is small. The capability of an inducer to avoid cavitation depends on its flow coefficient gp = Cmo/Uo, Where C9 (m/s) is the meridian velocity of the fluid at the inducer inlet, and uo (m/s) is the tangential velocity of the blade at the inlet tip.

anchors: What is required regarding the flow coefficient gp for a pump with high specific speed N to achieve high suction specific speed S?
positives: The value of the flow coefficient gp must be low for a pump of high specific speed N, in order for the pump to have a high value of suction specific speed S. To this end, the values of the angles 6, and 6), between the vanes and a plane perpendicular to the axis of rotation must  be small, as shown in the following figure, re-drawn from [22], which illustrates an inducer of low head rise, having three vanes and a non-tapered hub.

anchors: What factors influence the selection of materials for inducers based on their physical and mechanical characteristics?
positives: The materials of which inducers are made are usually chosen from alloys of stain- less steel (for example, 304 or 347), titanium (for example, Ti-SAI-2.5Sn ELI or Ti-6Al-4 V), and aluminium (for example, 7075-T73). The respective densities of these materials are approximately 8000, 4480, and 2810 kg/m?, and their strengths vary about in the same order as their densities. The choice of a specific material from those indicated above depends on their strength-to-weight ratio, chemical reactivity, cavitation erosion, and the need for special properties, such as ductility, notch tough- ness, etc.

anchors: What are the key advantages of using cast aluminium alloys over titanium alloys for low-stress applications?
positives: [4]. A cast aluminium alloy is the proper choice for an inducer subject to low stress when low cost is important. This is because aluminium is easy to forge and machine, but not apt to be welded or brazed. Titanium alloy parts are more expensive to machine than comparable parts of aluminium alloys, but less expensive than alloys such as Inconel® 718 or René® 41. Titanium alloys can be welded by gas-tungsten are or electron-beam processes. Proper welding procedures are to be observed for titanium alloys [4]..

anchors: What effect does pre-whirl of the inlet flow have on a pump's suction performance?
positives: An increase in the suction performance of a pump may be obtained by pre-whirl of the inlet flow. For this purpose, the inlet flow is mixed with high-velocity fluid taken from the pump discharge. This flow is injected through a ring of orifices in an axial direction upstream of the inducer. Pre-whirl introduced in this manner has improved flow distribution and reduced flow instabilities which may occur when a pump is throttled [4]..

anchors: What component can be added to minimize reverse fluid movement in an inducer operating below optimal flow conditions?
positives: Backflow occurs in an inducer at low flow (about 90% or less of the design value) as a result of local head breakdown in the tip region of the vanes. In order to reduce backflow or control its effects, a backflow deflector can be incorporated in the inlet line, as shown in the following figure, due to the courtesy of NASA [4].  || E Backflow

anchors: What effects does a deflector have on head and critical NPSH below nominal flow in fluid systems?
positives: Below nominal flow, (between 20 and 90% of the design flow) where back- flow becomes important, the deflector results in increased head, reduced critical NPSH, and lower amplitudes of low-frequency oscillations. Above nominal flow, the deflector has a detrimental effect [4]. Further information on backflow control can be found in [35].

anchors: What components are included in the design of a pump's housing, as described by Furst and Keller?
positives: The following part of the present section deals with the design of the housing, which is the envelope containing the pump. According to Furst and Keller [3], the housing consists of:

anchors: Identify the components involved in the construction of single-stage and multi-stage pumps, including the main enclosure and the systems affecting fluid flow.
positives: e the casing, which is the part of the pump containing the impeller; e the diffusing system and the volute for single-stage pumps; and e the crossover system for multi-stage pumps.

anchors: What is an example of a multi-stage pump specifically designed for liquid hydrogen, featuring back-to-back impellers and an external passage?
positives: An example of a multi-stage centrifugal-flow pump is the Centaur (RL-10) liquid- hydrogen pump, which has two stages mounted with the impellers back-to-back with volute housing and an external diffusing passage between the two stages, as shown in the following figure, due to the courtesy of NASA [3].  External diffusing ™~ passage rd ~ ax \ Volutes t x A ( . NS N qf Oe AN DSSS Impellers VN N “SS Ff § ‘ 4 External diffusing passage.

anchors: What types of diffusers can be incorporated within a diffusing system to manage flow before and after the volute?
positives: The diffusing system may include vaned or vaneless diffusers upstream of the volute and one or more conical diffusers downstream of the volute. The following figure, also due to the courtesy of NASA [3], shows three types of diffusing systems.WHA WI _ G@®_. (a) Votute (b) Vaneless diffuser (ce) Vaned diffuser plus plus volute folded volute

anchors: What components are included in the housing that provide support for the rotating element and ensure fluid does not escape?
positives: The housing also contains the bearings, which support the rotating element, and the seals, which prevent leakage of the pumped fluid.

anchors: What components of a pump facilitate the transformation of kinetic energy into pressure energy?
positives: The diffusing system and the volute form the part of the pump in which the kinetic energy impressed to the fluid by the rotating element is converted into pressure energy. The head loss due to friction at the inlet of a pump is very small, due to the short path and to the low velocity of the flow. The conical or cylindrical shape of the suction duct depends on whether the tip contour is or is not tapered.

anchors: What is the minimum clearance-to-blade length ratio achieved for fuel pumps in relation to inducer design?
positives: The best results have been obtained by tapering the contour of both the tip and the hub [22]. This is because the gradual reduction of the suction area upstream of the impeller eye makes the flow steady.  The rotating parts of oxidiser pumps must not be allowed to rub metal to metal. This rubbing may cause dangerous explosions in liquid-oxygen pumps. Practically attained minimum values of the inducer clearance-to-blade length ratio are 5% for fuel and 20% for oxidiser pumps.

anchors: What is the material used for the inducer casing lining when closer clearances are needed for oxidiser pumps?
positives: When closer clearances are required for oxidiser pumps, a liner made of PCTFE (Poly-Chloro-Tri-Fluoro-Ethylene, whose trade name is Kel-F® or Neoflon®) should be used for the inducer casing. The chemical formula of this polymer is (CF,CCIF),, where n is the number of monomer units in its molecule. A layer of this material, 2.54 mm in thickness, is inserted between the tips of the inducer blades and the wall of the suction duct, as shown in the following figure, due to the courtesy of NASA [4].

anchors: What is the nominal value of radial clearance for the inducer?
positives: Wy nin ek NZ ) LOX inlet ENA RAN ANS VA Coated inlet Present inlet radial clearance tadial clearance Inducer 0.005 nominal 0.107 nominal.

anchors: What is the primary mechanism for converting velocity head to pressure head in a system without static vanes?
positives: As has been shown here and also in Sect. 4.5, the diffusing system may, or may not, have static vanes. In case of a vaneless diffuser, the pumped fluid at the outlet of the impeller is discharged into a single volute channel, whose cross section increases gradually, and the conversion from velocity head to pressure head takes place principally in the conical nozzle at the outlet of the pump.

anchors: What are the efficiency differences between a vaned diffuser and a vaneless diffuser in fluid dynamics?
positives: In case of a vaned diffuser, the pumped fluid at the outlet of the impeller is discharged into a diffuser provided with vanes, and the same conversion takes place prevalently in the channels between the diffusing vanes, before the fluid has reached the volute channel. A vaneless diffuser has the advantage of simplicity, but a vaned diffuser is more efficient than the other.

anchors: What are the primary design specifications for a centrifugal-flow pump featuring a vaneless diffuser and a single outlet?
positives: The principal design parameters of a vaneless-diffuser, single outlet, centrifugal- flow pump are shown in the following figure, re-drawn from [22].  Les) =: DIAMETER d, Fey ae by 9s

anchors: What angle must the flow direction at the impeller exit align with to prevent downstream turbulence and wear?
positives: These parameters are the area A, (m7) of the volute at the throat, the flow area Ag (m7), the angle 0, (rad) between the side walls of the volute, the volute tongue angle a, (rad), the radius 7, (m) at which the volute tongue starts, and the width b3 (m) of the volute. By volute tongue angle aw, we mean the camber angle formed by the tongue with the circumferential direction [25]. The direction of the flow at the exit of the impeller must match the angle @,,, in order to avoid turbulence and wear downstream of the tongue.

anchors: What is the relationship between the volute tongue angle and the angle of the absolute velocity vector at the impeller outlet?
positives: For this purpose, the value of the volute tongue angle a, is chosen close to the value of the angle a’ between the absolute velocity vector c’> and the peripheral velocity vector u2 at the outlet of the impeller, that is, a, ~ a’. The values of the other parameters are discussed below, in accordance with the indications given in [22]..

anchors: What methods are utilized to find the area of the volute's cross-section at a specific angular distance from the tongue?
positives: The methods used to determine the cross-sectional area Ag of the volute at an angular distance 6 (rad) from the volute tongue are: (a) constant moment of momentum per unit mass; and (b) constant mean velocity.

anchors: How is the circumferential component of absolute velocity in a volute related to the radius, assuming no friction losses?
positives: In the method (a), the circumferential component c’,3 of the absolute velocity of the pumped fluid in the volute is assumed to be inversely proportional to the radius r (c'.3 r = constant), which would be true only in the absence of friction losses. After the shape of the volute has been determined, the volute cross-sectional area satisfying the given flow requirement is determined at each circumferential station.

anchors: What design approach was utilized for developing the pump housing in both Titan I and II, as well as the J-2S Mark 29 fuel pump?
positives: This method was used for the design of the pump housing of Titan I and Titan II. It was also used, corrected for friction losses, for the design of the J-2S Mark 29 fuel pump (illustrated in Sect. 4.7), which experienced very light radial bearing loads [3]..

anchors: What is the relationship between the area of the volute at an angular distance and the volume flow rate of the pump?
positives: In the method (b), the mean absolute velocity c’3 (m/s) of the pumped fluid in the volute is assumed to be constant at all cross sections of the volute over the circum- ference, and therefore the area Ay of each cross section is increased proportionally to the increase in the central angle 6 of the volute. In other terms, the constant mean absolute velocity c’3 is made equal to  gat bs “A, 2m Ao where q (m?/s) is the volume flow rate of the pump, A, (m7) is the area of the volute at the throat (where 6 = 0), and Ay (m7) is the area of the volute at an angular distance 6 (rad) from the volute tongue. This method was conceived to simplify the volute design..

anchors: What factors contribute to the differences in hydraulic forces experienced by the impeller in various pump design methods?
positives: There are only small differences in pump efficiency between the two methods. The unsymmetrical pressure (with its associated radial hydraulic forces upon the impeller) around the volute passage has been found to be higher in pumps designed according to the constant-mean-velocity method [3].The design value of the mean absolute velocity c’3 (m/s) can be determined from the following correlation

positives: cy = KyQgoAH)? where K,, is a design factor, whose value (determined experimentally and ranging from 0.15 to 0.55) is lower for pumps of higher specific speed, AH (m) is the design head rise of the pump, and go = 9.80665 m/s? is the acceleration of gravity near the surface of the Earth.

anchors: What is the acceptable range for the radius where the volute tongue begins, in relation to the outer radius of the impeller, to prevent turbulence?
positives: The radius r, at which the volute tongue starts should be from 1.05 to 1.1 times the outer radius rz of the impeller, in order to avoid turbulence.

anchors: What is the width ratio of the volute at the bottom of its trapezoidal cross section to the impeller width for low specific speed pumps?
positives: The width b3 of the volute at the bottom of its trapezoidal cross section is chosen to be 2.0 times b2 (where bp is the impeller width at the outlet) in case of pumps of low specific speeds, and from 1.6 to 1.75 times b2 in case of pumps of high specific speeds.

anchors: What recommendation is given for the angle between the side walls of the volute for pumps with high specific speeds?
positives: The maximum value of the angle 6, between the side walls of the volute should be about z/3 radians. A value smaller than this should be chosen for pumps of high specific speeds or high flow angles a’ at the impeller outlet.

anchors: What design feature is implemented in centrifugal-flow pumps to minimize the radial force on the impeller shaft due to pressure variations?
positives: The pressure exerted by the pumped fluid on the walls of the volute cannot be kept uniform under all operating conditions. Consequently, the impeller shaft is subject to a radial force. In order to eliminate or reduce this force, double-volute housings are used. A typical double-volute, single-outlet housing of a centrifugal-flow pump is shown in the following figure, re-drawn from [22].  DIRECTION OF FLOW | : 7 ROTATION.

anchors: What effect does the second tongue in a double-volute housing have on the total resultant radial force in flow?
positives: In the double-volute housing illustrated above, the flow forms two streams as a result of a second tongue placed at an angular distance of z radians from the first. This symmetry in the flow may reduce the total resultant radial force.

anchors: What is the advantage of using a diffuser with static vanes compared to a vaneless diffuser in terms of fluid flow and pressure conversion?
positives: A diffuser provided with static vanes has been illustrated in Sect. 4.5. The shape of the volute of a vaned diffuser is the same as that of a vaneless diffuser, but a vaned diffuser has a plurality of passages through which the pumped fluid flows from the impeller to the discharge nozzle. This fact makes it possible to convert the velocity head possessed by the fluid into pressure head in a narrower space than is the case with a vaneless diffuser.

anchors: What is the recommended ratio of the vaned diffuser width at the inlet compared to the impeller width at the outlet?
positives: High performance is obtained by a small radial distance (from 0.8 to 3.0 mm, depending on the impeller diameter) between the impeller and the inlet tips of the static vanes. The width of a vaned diffuser at the inlet may be chosen to be from 1.6 to 2.0 times b) (where b is the impeller width at the outlet). With reference to the following figure, re-drawn from [22], the vane angle a3 at the inlet should be chosen equal or close to the angle a’, between the vectors c’2 and uz at the outlet of the impeller. anchors: What is the relationship between height and width at the throat of each passage in the described system?
positives: The height /3 (m) and the width b3 (m) at the throat of each passage between twocontiguous vanes in a diffuser are chosen so that 3 = b3. The angle of divergence of  each passage downstream of the throat is chosen in the range from 7/18 to 27/15 rad. The velocity of the flow downstream of the diffuser is kept a little higher than its velocity in the discharge line of the pump [22].

anchors: What are the two methods mentioned for creating components in a fabrication process?
positives: (a) casting in one or more pieces; (b) welding together forged, formed, cast, or machined elements.

anchors: What types of materials are typically utilized for constructing diffuser and guide vanes in engineering applications?
positives: Materials used for this purpose are cast aluminium alloys, cast stainless steels, and high-strength wrought aluminium alloys and steels. Diffuser vanes can be integral or separate. Reinforcing bolts through diffuser or guide vanes have been used to provide structural aid. Housing structures must bear mounting loads and loads due to internal pressure. External loads on the volute can be reduced by using flexible ducts [3]..

anchors: What factors contribute to the increase in stress acting on a housing structure beyond the initially provided values?
positives: The stress acting really on a housing structure is higher than the one expressed above, due to discontinuities and deformation of the wall, and also to thermal stresses resulting from temperature gradients across the wall [22].

positives: =a(—) = 3.1416 x (——— ) = 0.03281 m* 2 2 The velocities c; and c, of the flow at respectively the inlet and the outlet of the discharge nozzle are 0.7836 c= b= = 30.48 mis A; 0.01985 ce = 1 = 08% _ 53.88 mis A. 0.03281 As has been shown in Sect. 4.5, a thrust balance system is necessary to counteract the axial loads generated by changes of axial momentum and of pressure in the  pumped fluid. anchors: What design adjustment can decrease loads in propellant pump systems, as implemented in the Mark 3 turbo-pump?
positives: These loads can be reduced by mounting the two propellant pumps back to back. This, together with the mounting of radial ribs, has been done in the Mark 3 turbo- pump, which has been described in detail in Sect. 4.5. Other methods, used either alone or in conjunction one with another, are described below.

anchors: What is the purpose of a balance chamber located behind the impeller's wearing ring?
positives: A method consists in installing a wearing ring which provides a balance chamber at the back shroud of the impeller. This balance chamber is a space located between the back wearing ring (of diameter d),) and the shaft seal (of diameter d,), as shown in the following figure, adapted from [3].

anchors: How can the pressure in a balance chamber be regulated?
positives: The axial loads are balanced by choosing properly the diameter d;,, the diameter d;, and the value of the pressure p, of the fluid admitted into the balance chamber. The value of the pressure p, can be controlled by adjusting the clearances and the leakages of the back wearing ring and of the shaft seals.

anchors: What is the effect of the impeller's rotational motion on the pressure exerted by the fluid as the radial distance increases?
positives: The radial ribs reduce the static pressure in the space between the back shroud of the impeller and the wall of the casing, because the pumped fluid spins in this space with the impeller. This rotational motion decreases the pressure exerted by the fluid with the radial distance from the impeller tips [12]. Holes may be provided through the impeller into the inside diameter region of the radial ribs to vent that region statically and to provide a positive coolant flow into the radial ribs to prevent cavitation caused by fluid heating which results from the pumping work of the radial ribs [3]. .

anchors: What design feature in the F-1 engine's oxidiser pump impeller helps manage axial force alongside radial ribs?
positives: The gear-driven pumps of the Titan launch vehicles had open-face impellers with radial ribs in the impeller hub, in order to reduce the axial force to a value which could be sustained by a split-inner-race ball bearing. The turbo-pump of the F-1 engine had shrouded impellers. In order to control the axial force, the impeller of the oxidiser pump of the F-1 engine had an inlet wear ring and radial ribs, whereas the impeller of the fuel pump of the same engine had inlet and hub wear rings.

anchors: What type of bearings are used to support the unbalanced axial force in the system described?
positives: The pump forces balanced the direct-drive turbine forces, so that tandem split-inner-race ball bearings could sustain the unbalanced axial force [3]. .

What technique is employed in the Mark 48-O turbo-pump to manage axial thrust between its pump and turbine?
positives: Still another method to control axial thrust in a centrifugal-flow pump uses a self-compensating balance piston. This method was used in the Mark 48-O (liquid oxygen) turbo-pump, which was designed to achieve a balance of axial thrust between the pump and the turbine. For this purpose, the back side of the pump impeller contains a balance piston, which is shown in the following figure, due to the courtesy of NASA [37].

anchors: What is the flow path of liquid oxygen from the impeller discharge to the eye of the impeller in a balancing system?
positives: The rotating member of the balance piston is the rear shroud of the impeller. To operate the piston, high-pressure liquid oxygen from the impeller discharge passes through a high-pressure orifice located at the outer diameter of the impeller into the balance piston cavity. From this cavity, the liquid oxygen passes through a low-pressure orifice near the impeller hub into the balance piston sump. From there, the liquid oxygen returns to the eye of the impeller through axial passages in the diffuser vanes and radial holes in the diffuser and inlet [38].

anchors: What effect does an unbalanced load toward the pump inlet have on the gaps of high-pressure and low-pressure openings?
positives: The thrust-compensating effect is obtained because the openings of the high- pressure orifice and of the low-pressure orifice vary with the axial position of the rotor. Therefore, the axial force due to the pressure on the rear shroud of the impeller varies correspondingly. For example, an unbalanced load toward the pump inlet causes a reduction in the high-pressure orifice gap and an increase in the low-pressure orifice gap. This, in turn, causes a reduction in the pressure force of the impeller rear shroud, introducing a compensating load change [38]..

anchors: What factors are considered when selecting materials for thrust balance systems, specifically regarding safety and compatibility with propellant?
positives: Materials used for thrust balance systems are chosen taking account of their compatibility with the propellant, strength at the required rotating speed, and safety in the event of an inadvertent rub. Plastic materials such as PCTFE (Poly-Chloro- Tri-Fluoro-Ethylene, whose trade name is Kel-F® or Neoflon®), PTFE (Poly-Tetra- Fluoro-Ethylene, whose trade name is Teflon®), and fluorinated PVC (Poly-Vinyl- Chloride) resist burning if rubbed on the impeller in liquid-oxygen pumps, and there- fore are safe stationary sealing materials when the difference of the seal pressure is not excessive.

anchors: What type of pumps are suitable for certain materials regarding liquid hydrogen?
positives: These materials are also satisfactory for liquid-hydrogen pumps.  Materials for balance-piston orifices are chosen to resist galling if rubbed against.

anchors: What properties must materials possess for orifices in liquid-oxygen pumps to ensure safety and stability?
positives: balance-piston rotor or impeller materials. In case of balance pistons used in liquid- oxygen pumps, materials used for orifices must resist explosion or ignition upon impact, and must also be physically and chemically stable in liquid oxygen. The following table, due to the courtesy of NASA [3], indicates materials used for thrust balance systems.

anchors: What is the equivalent pressure rise in pascals for a head rise of 19,800 meters in a liquid hydrogen system?
positives: “Material Suitable for use with LOX 4.10 Design of Axial-Flow Pumps Apart from the case of inducers, axial-flow pumps have been used in rocket engines only when the pumped propellant is liquid hydrogen, because this fluid requires high values of volume flow rate and head rise. For this purpose, such pumps have been used in the multi-stage configuration only. The head rise AH made available by a typical single-stage centrifugal-flow pump, when the pumped fluid is liquid hydrogen, is about 19,800 m, which corresponds to a pressure rise Ap of about 70.85 x 9.807 x 19,800 = 1.376 x 107 N/m?.

anchors: What is the typical head rise range provided by each stage of a multi-stage axial-flow pump?
positives: This is due to the very low density p = 70.85 kg/m? of liquid hydrogen. When higher values then these are required for AH and Ap, then a multi-stage axial-flow pump is chosen. A pump of the latter type makes it possible to obtain a head rise ranging from about 1520 to 2740 m for each stage [22]..

anchors: What is the minimum allowable volume flow rate for axial-flow pumps designed for liquid hydrogen in m³/s?
positives: The volume flow rate q of axial-flow pumps used for liquid hydrogen cannot be lower than about 0.347 m?/s, because the height of the rotor or stator vanes of such pumps cannot be lower than about 12.7 mm, for manufacturing reasons. For values greater than 0.347 m/s of volume flow rate and in the range from 9140 to 19,800 m of head rise, the design requirements of a liquid-hydrogen pump can be satisfied by either a single-stage centrifugal flow pump or a multi-stage axial flow pump.

anchors: What is the maximum volume flow rate for liquid hydrogen that warrants the use of a centrifugal-flow pump?
positives: In practice, a centrifugal-flow pump for liquid hydrogen is chosen when the volume flow rate required is lower than 0.0158 m/s [22]..

anchors: What is the implication of maintaining a constant meridian component of velocity in all stages of an axial-flow pump?
positives: The meridian or axial component c,, of the absolute velocity vector ¢ of the flow is assumed to have a constant value in all the stages (rotor and stator) of an axial-flow pump. This assumption requires a constant area of the cross section of the pump, in order for the equation of continuity of flow to be satisfied. By so doing, the effects of frictional drag at the walls of the housing and at the vanes are neglected..

anchors: What component of the absolute velocity vector remains unchanged as fluid flows between the rotor and stator in an axial-flow pump?
positives: The stator of an axial-flow pump converts much of the head of the pumped fluid due to the tangential component c’,,3 of its absolute velocity vector c’3 at the outlet of the rotor vanes into pressure head. For this purpose, the curvature of the stator vanes is such as to reduce the tangential component of the absolute velocity vector of the flow. By contrast, the axial component c’,,3 of the vector c’3 does not change, because the passages between stator and rotor perpendicular to the axial direction have the same cross-sectional area.

anchors: How does the chord-to-pitch ratio of the stator vanes change with varying diameters from the hub to the tip?
positives: The diameters d, (m) and d;, (m) of the stator at respectively the tip and the hub can be considered equal to the diameters of the rotor at respectively the tip and the hub. The value of the chord-to-pitch ratio C,/P, of the stator vanes increases as their diameter increases from d;, to d,. The length L, (m) of the stator vanes in the axial direction is usually chosen equal to the length L, (m) of the rotor vanes in the same direction..

anchors: What adjustment is made to the vane angles at the inlet of the stator vanes to enhance fluid deflection?
positives: The velocity diagrams at the inlet and at the outlet of the stator vanes are drawn assuming the absolute flow velocities and the angles to be equal to the absolute velocities and to the angles at the inlet and at the outlet of the rotor vanes. The vane angles a3 at the inlet of the stator vanes are chosen slightly greater than the angles a’; formed there by the absolute velocity vector c’; with the tangential direction (a3 = a’; + i), in order for the fluid to be deflected effectively.

anchors: What is the range for the impeller hub diameter to tip diameter ratio in liquid-hydrogen axial-flow pumps?
positives: Typical design values for these quantities are given below for liquid-hydrogen axial-flow pumps, according to [22]. The ratio ry = d;,/d, of the impeller hub diameter dj, to the impeller tip diameter d, ranges from 0.76 to 0.86. The specific speed for each stage (NV), ranges from 1.1 to 1.8. The head coefficient for each stage (Ww); = g0(AH),/u2, ranges from 0.25 to 0.35. The solidity of the rotor vanes S, = C,/P, at the mean effective diameter ranges from 1.0 to 1.3.

anchors: What is the required characteristic of the number of rotor vanes to prevent resonance with the stator vanes in an impeller rotor?
positives: The solidity of the stator vanes S, = C,/P, at the mean effective diameter ranges from 1.5 to 1.8. The number of vanes of the rotor Z, ranges from 14 to 20. The number of vanes of the stator Z, ranges from 35 to 45. The value of Z, should have no common factor with the value of Z,, in order to avoid resonance phenomena. The head rise produced by the moving vanes of an impeller rotor depends on the value of the angular difference B; — f, called vane curvature..

anchors: What is the key difference in design methodology between a multi-stage axial-flow pump and a single-stage centrifugal pump?
positives: The design method used for a multi-stage axial-flow pump is similar to the method described in Sect. 4.9, which relates to a single-stage centrifugal pump. The difference between the two methods consists in the determination of the number of stages of the axial-flow pump. The latter method is described below. The system requirements relating to the rocket engines give the values of some basic quantities, such as the total head rise AH (m) of the pump, the volume flow rate g (m/s), and the required net positive suction head (NPSH) x (m).

anchors: What manufacturing process is utilized for the Mark 9 and Mark 25 pump rotors as opposed to that of the Mark 15-F and Mark 26?
positives: A one-piece rotor structure, machined from a single forging, has been used for the Mark 15-F (see part (A) of the preceding figure) and Mark 26 pump rotors. Axial holes have been machined in the forging to provide a return flow path for thrust balance system and bearing coolant flows. The Mark 9 (see part (B) of the preceding figure) and Mark 25 pump rotors have been fabricated according to the build-up concept with the disks and stub shafts clamped together through bolts.

anchors: What method is employed to achieve radial positioning in the described structure?
positives: Rabbets have been used to attain relative radial positioning, the torque loads being transmitted by shear in the tie bolts. The M-1 rotor (see part (C) of the preceding figure) is a hollow structure fabricated from four forged and machined ring components TIG-welded together [2]..

anchors: What is the design characteristic of the hub in an inducer used for an axial-flow pump regarding its diameter from inlet to outlet?
positives: the method described in Sect. 4.9, which relates to an inducer for a centrifugal-flow pump. The inducer used for an axial-flow pump has often a cylindrical casing, vanes of a constant tip diameter, and a highly tapered hub. In other words, the hub diameter increases from a small value at the inlet of the inducer to a greater value at the outlet of the inducer, at which point the hub diameter is close to the impeller diameter.

anchors: What is the primary function of the inducer stator in fluid dynamics systems?
positives: A stationary part of the inducer (inducer stator) is placed downstream of the rotating part. The inducer stator is aimed at converting much of the velocity head, imparted to the pumped fluid by the rotating part of the inducer, into pressure head. The inducer stator is also aimed at discharging the fluid so that its absolute velocity vector c’> should have a magnitude c’, and a direction a’, as close as possible to respectively the magnitude c’, and the direction a’, of the absolute velocity vector c’, of the fluid at the outlet of the impeller stator..

positives: According to Huzel and Huang [22], the solidity of the inducer stator vanes Sj = Cj;/Pis ranges from 1.5 to 1.8. The number of the inducer stator vanes Z;; ranges from 15 to 20. The value of Z;; should have no common factor with the value of the impeller rotor vanes Z,, in order to avoid resonance phenomena.

anchors: What is the primary function of vanes in the exit passage of an axial-flow pump?
positives: The volute portion of an axial-flow pump is designed so that the flow from the last axial stage is ducted to an exit passage, and is gradually turned toward a plane normal to the rotation axis of the pump, before being collected in the volute proper. Vanes are used in the exit passage to guide and diffuse the flow, and also to tie the volute walls together structurally. The volute portion of the Mark 15-F pump and its diffuser vanes are shown in the following figure, adapted from [2].  PUMP VOLUTE T+<7* RZ | Z oa LaNe* SS ; ZZ LPS Va DIFFUSER Ni au (2 sy THRUST-.

anchors: What advantage does a folded volute provide in terms of housing size and weight compared to other designs?
positives: A folded volute permits a smaller overall housing envelope, which results in a lower weight. In addition, a folded volute can be used to obtain a single-vortex rather than double-vortex motion in the volute. This kind of motion is particularly effective to increase efficiency in a volute-exit conical diffuser and to stabilise performance [2].

anchors: What is the recommended range for the quantity of diffuser vanes in a specific design?
positives: The number of diffuser vanes ranges usually from 17 to 23 [22]. This number should have no common factor with the number of impeller rotor vanes, in order to avoid resonance phenomena. The vane angle a,, shown in the following figure, adapted from [2], can be determined by drawing the velocity diagrams for the diffuser vanes. The line, which forms the angle a, with the chord line, is normal to the plane of the row of diffuser vanes.  a LINE MEAN CAMBER se an LINE Sng FA “sy Z fa >; a *.

anchors: What is the typical range for design flow velocity in the volute of axial-flow pumps for liquid hydrogen?
positives: Incase of axial-flow pumps for liquid hydrogen, the design velocity of flow in the volute ranges from 30.5 to 45.7 m/s [22]. The cross section of the volute has usually a circular shape, due to the high pressure. The boil-off of liquid hydrogen is limited as far as possible by using high-quality thermal insulating materials applied to the external surface of the pump.

anchors: What components are utilized in an axial-flow turbo-pump to manage high axial thrust stemming from pressure forces and fluid momentum variations?
positives: In an axial-flow turbo-pump, thrust bearings and compensating balance pistons are used to counteract the high axial thrust loads due to pressure forces and fluid momentum changes in the pump and in the turbine [2].

anchors: What component in the Mark 15-F turbo-pump ensures balanced pressure and supports rotational elements?
positives: The following figure, due to the courtesy of NASA [36], shows the balance piston and bearing scheme chosen for the Mark 15-F turbo-pump.  Balance piston BY (AZZ? = LL ies ma ie a) Gh Y iy p ZZ Spring preloaded ball bearings

anchors: What component of the rotor assembly includes variable openings and two seals located on the front and rear sides?
positives: The balance piston, which is part of the rotor assembly, is a disk having variable orifices with a pair of seal rubs located one on the front side (left in the figure) and the other on the rear side (right in the figure) of the disk. High-pressure fluid coming from the pump discharge is introduced into the thrust balance system and flows through the two variable orifices in series with a low-pressure area..

anchors: What effect does a reduction of pressure in the control chamber have on the motion of the rotor assembly in a pump?
positives: When an axial thrust moves the rotor assembly toward the inducer of the pump, then the balance piston closes the high-pressure orifice at the front seal rub and opens the low-pressure orifice at the rear seal rub, thereby reducing the pressure in the control chamber placed between the two seal rubs. This reduction of pressure counteracts the hydraulic axial thrust acting on the rotor assembly toward the inducer, and restrains the motion of the rotor assembly in that direction.

anchors: What mechanism counteracts the reverse axial force on the rotor assembly when it shifts towards the pump discharge?
positives: Likewise, when a reverse axial thrust moves the rotor assembly towards the discharge of the pump, then the balance piston opens the high-pressure orifice at the front seal rub and closes the low-pressure orifice at the rear seal rub, thereby increasing the pressure in the control chamber placed between the two seal rubs. This increase in pressure counteracts the reverse axial thrust acting on the rotor assembly toward the discharge, and causes the rotor assembly to return to its neutral position.

This is because impulse turbines are simpler and lighter than reaction turbines.

anchors: How does the required power influence the number of stages in a rocket engine turbine design?
positives: The design of a turbine for a rocket engine is based on the following considerations. The number of stages depends on the power required.

anchors: What is the formula for calculating the isentropic velocity ratio for a single-stage turbine?
positives: As has been shown in Sect. 4.3, the design isentropic velocity ratio determines the range of efficiency of a turbine. The isentropic velocity ratio for a single-stage turbine is U/Co, where U (m/s) is the peripheral velocity of the blades, Co = (2 Ahr)? (m/s) is the isentropic spouting velocity, and Ahr (J/kg) is the enthalpy drop per unit mass of the working fluid through a turbine. For a N-stage turbine, the isentropic velocity ratio is (U7 + U3 + --- + U2)*/Co.

anchors: What factors influence the peak efficiency observed in impulse and reaction staging turbines as indicated by a graph of velocity ratio?
positives: A plot of isentropic velocity ratio versus turbine efficiency 77 is given in the following figure, due to the courtesy of NASA [15], which illustrates the variation in peak efficiency for 1-, 2-, and 3-row impulse staging turbines and for reaction staging turbines.  oe 100.

anchors: What are the values of the isentropic velocity ratio measured in units ranging from 0.015 to 1.00?
What is the typical range for design isentropic velocity ratios in two-row turbines used in specific engine cycles?
positives: These curves make it possible to establish and compare initial estimates of effi- ciency for turbines of new design. In practice, design isentropic velocity ratios for two-row turbines used in gas-generator and tap-off engine cycles (see Sect. 4.4) range from 0.1 to 0.4, and corresponding efficiencies vary from 35 to 65% [15]. Staged- combustion and expander-cycle turbines reach efficiencies above 80%, because the lower values of the turbine system pressure ratio po/p. permit operation in a range of velocity ratios corresponding to higher efficiency, as has been shown quantitatively in Sect. 4.8..

anchors: What is the range of peripheral velocities experienced by current turbine blades in meters per second?
positives: Peripheral velocities U of current turbine blades vary from 305 to 457 m/s, and associated inlet temperatures for liquid oxygen/RP-1 and for liquid oxygen/liquid hydrogen turbines range from 811 to 1089 K. Rocket engine turbines have been operated successfully without cooling at inlet temperatures of 1200 K [15].

anchors: What factors influence the number of stages in a newly designed turbine?
positives: The number of stages in a turbine of new design depends on the quantity of energy possessed by the unit mass of the working fluid and made available to the turbine. It also depends on a compromise between a gain in turbine efficiency and the added mass due to the further turbine stages required to increase performance. In a study of staging, pressure ratios and enthalpies per unit mass are varied in several possible configurations, to determine the design point corresponding to the highest efficiency with the smallest pitch diameter and the least number of stages.

anchors: What are the two types of axial turbines commonly used, and what design specification is often applied regarding impulse-type staging?
positives: Current turbines are usually of the single-row or two-row axial type. This is due principally to size and mass restrictions affecting turbines used for rocket engines. Impulse-type staging is usually specified in turbines of new design with isentropic velocity ratios below 0.35. These turbines operate with high-energy working fluids and at pressure ratios which raise the stage spouting velocity into the supersonic domain.

anchors: What type of turbine is generally selected for a direct-drive arrangement with a low pressure ratio and specific velocity characteristics?
positives: Reaction turbines are used with low pressure ratios (<2) and isentropic velocity ratios above 0.45 [15].  In a direct-drive arrangement, when the pumps and the turbine are mounted on a single shaft, the rotating speed w (rad/s) of the turbine and therefore the isentropic velocity ratio U/Co have values lower than the ideal ones. In this arrangement, a single-stage, two-row, velocity-compounded impulse turbine is generally chosen, as is the case with the Mark 10 turbo-pump illustrated in the following figure, adapted from [5]. anchors: What is the speed reduction ratio for the input and pump-shaft in the Mark 3 turbo-pump?
positives: By contrast, in a geared, offset-turbine arrangement, the presence of a gearbox makes it possible to operate the turbine at rotational speeds much higher than those which are possible with a direct-drive arrangement. For example, for the Mark 3 turbo-pump described at length in Sect. 4.5, the input rotational speed is 3434.8 rad/s, and the speed reduction ratio input/pump-shaft is 4.885 for both of the pumps [15]. Consequently, the Mark 3 turbo-pump has a two-stage, pressure-compounded impulse turbine..

anchors: What properties of the working fluid, including specific heat ratio, are essential for determining the rotor size of an impulse turbine?
positives: After the type of impulse turbine and the number of its stages have been deter- mined, it is necessary to determine the size of its rotor. To this end, it is necessary to know the properties (inlet temperature To, specific heat ratio y, etc.) of the working fluid, the pressure ratio po/p- of the turbine, and the rotation speed w of the pumps.

anchors: What factors must be balanced when selecting the rotor tip diameter to optimize performance while managing size and stress levels?
positives: The rotor tip diameter d, (m) is chosen by taking account that a large diameter results in a high isentropic velocity ratio U/Co and a high efficiency 7, but also in high size, high mass, and high stresses in operating conditions. Therefore, the rotor tip diameter results from a compromise.

anchors: What factors must be summed to determine the useful power delivered by the turbine shaft?
positives: The useful power Py (W) delivered by the turbine shaft must be equal to the sum of the net power required by the pumps, the power loss in the gearbox (if any), and the power required by auxiliary drives. After the power resulting from this sum has been determined, the required mass flow rate my (kg/s) of the working fluid can be determined by using the following equation of Sect. 4.8:

anchors: What transformation occurs to the working fluid's energy as it traverses through the pathways of an impulse turbine?
positives: The nozzles convert the potential energy of the working fluid into kinetic energy by reducing the temperature and the pressure of the fluid as it passes through the vane channels. The kinetic energy is then converted to work as the working fluid passes through the rotor blades [15]. The path followed by the working fluid through a two- row impulse turbine as that of the Mark 10 turbo-pump is shown in the following figure, re-drawn from [22].  FLOW.

anchors: What components are referred to when discussing rotor and stator elements in a mechanical system?

anchors: What effects lead to the actual exit velocity of gas in a nozzle being lower than the velocity calculated under ideal expansion conditions?
positives: The expansion of a gas flowing through an actual nozzle is not isentropic, due to the viscosity of the working fluid, friction, boundary-layer effects, etc. The loss of kinetic energy due to friction and turbulence in the flow causes an increase in temperature (reheat) in the gas flowing through a nozzle. Therefore, the actual velocity C, of the gas at the exit of a nozzle is lower than its spouting velocity Co, which is calculated assuming an isentropic expansion.

anchors: What factors contribute to the effective area of a nozzle being less than its geometric area?

anchors: What are the primary elements that make up Stellite® 21, and what properties does it enhance in its applications?
positives: Stellite® 21 is a cobalt-chromium alloy, which is designed to be resistant to wear, corrosion, and heat. The alloys of the Stellite group may also have some portions of tungsten or molybdenum and some small but critical amounts of carbon. Stellite is a trademarked name of Deloro Stellite Company supplying Stellite alloys like Stellite 3, Stellite 6, Stellite 12 and Stellite 21.

anchors: What types of properties make certain nickel-chromium based super-alloys suitable for high-temperature applications?
positives: Inconel® (comprising 713C, 718, X-750, ...) is a family of austenitic nickel- chromium based super-alloys having excellent resistance to oxidation and thermal fatigue, as has been shown in Chap. 2, Sect. 2.5.

anchors: What is the primary ingredient in the metal alloys referred to as high-performance alloys?
positives: Hastelloy® is a registered trademark name of Haynes International, Inc., which is applied as the prefix name of a range of corrosion-resistant metal alloys under the term super-alloys or high-performance alloys. The principal ingredient of these alloys is nickel. Other ingredients are molybdenum, chromium, cobalt, iron, copper,  manganese, titanium, zirconium, aluminium, carbon, and tungsten in various percent- ages. The primary quality of the Hastelloy alloys is resistance to high thermal and mechanical stresses..

anchors: What is the term for the distance between corresponding points of two adjacent blades, measured at the mean diameter?
positives: The tip and the hub are respectively the outermost section and the innermost section of a blade.The radial height /, (m) of a blade is the difference between its radius at the tip and its radius at the hub.The blade pitch P, (m) or blade spacing, measured at the mean diameter d,,,, is the distance in the direction of rotation between corresponding points of two adjacent blades.

anchors: What is the description of the surface on a blade where maximum pressure is achieved?
positives: The pressure surface is the concave surface of a blade, where the pressure reaches its maximum value.

anchors: Define the terms leading edge, trailing edge, and chord line as they relate to a blade's geometry.
positives: The suction surface is the convex surface of a blade, where the pressure reaches its minimum value.The leading edge and the trailing edge are respectively the front (or nose) and the rear (or tail) of a blade.The chord line is the line between the two points in which the front and the rear of a blade section touch a flat surface, on which the blade section is placed with its convex surface upside.

anchors: What is the approximate length of the perpendicular projection of the blade profile onto the chord line in relation to the distance between the leading and trailing edges?
positives: The chord C, (m) is the length of the perpendicular projection of the blade profile onto the chord line. This length is approximately equal to the distance between the leading edge and the trailing edge.

anchors: What defines the camber line of a blade profile in a turbine?
positives: The axial chord is the length of the projection of a blade, as set in the turbine, onto a line parallel to the turbine axis.The camber line is the mean line of a blade profile, and extends from the leading edge to the trailing edge, halfway between the pressure surface and the suction surface.

anchors: What is the external angle created by the tangents at both edges of a camber line called?
positives: The camber angle is the external angle formed by the intersection of the tangents to the camber line at the leading edge and at the trailing edge.

anchors: What defines the relationship between a blade's height and its axial length in turbine design?
positives: The stagger angle is the angle between the chord line and the axial direction of the turbine.The blade aspect ratio is the ratio of the height h, to the axial length C;, of a blade. Design values of the aspect ratio range from 1.3 to 2.5 [22].The solidity of a blade is the ratio of its chord C; to the pitch P, of the blade. Design values of a blade solidity range from 1.4 to 2.0 [22].

anchors: What factors influence the required number of rotor blades to effectively direct flow in a system?
positives: The nozzle pitch P,, and the blade pitch P,, can be chosen independently from each other, as long as the number Z, of the rotor blades is sufficient to direct the flow. This number depends on the aspect ratio and on the solidity of the blades, and should not have any common factor with the number of the nozzles or with the number of the stator blades.

anchors: What shapes are combined in the design of a blade profile according to the given description?
positives: A blade profile has segments of straight lines combined with circular arcs or parabolic arcs or both. anchors: What are the angles formed by the tangents at the endpoints of a blade's circular arc relative to its direction of rotation?
positives: The pressure surface of the blade is concave, and the radius of its circular arc is designated with rr. The suction side of the blade is convex, and the radius of its circular arc is designated with r,. The two tangents at the two endpoints of the circular arc on the pressure side form two angles (0,; and 6). at respectively the inlet and the outlet of the blade) with the direction of rotation. The thickness of the blade at its leading edge and at its trailing edge is designated with t,..

If it were otherwise (0,; < £1), the flowing gas would impinge on the blades just at the inlet, with consequent losses. The angle 6,2 is usually chosen equal to the angle 62 formed by the relative velocity vector V2 with the direction of rotation at the outlet of the rotor blades. .
